item.title: Large Hadron Collider
item.dc:creator: @dragonfire455 dragonfire455
item.description:
@dragonfire455 wrote:

Looks like they’re pretty secure

Part of the computer system of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) was hacked into as the world's most powerful physics experiment got under way.

A group calling itself the “Greek Security Team” hacked into a computer connected to the system last Wednesday.

A spokesman for Cern, the lab that houses the LHC, said the hackers put up a message on the facility’s website.

No harm was done but the incident has highlighted the need for security in the LHC’s network, the spokesman said.

The hackers had targeted the computer network of the Compact Muon Solenoid Experiment (CMS), a huge detector that analyses data from the particle accelerator.


what a 1337 way to die

Read full topic

item.title: Large Hadron Collider
item.dc:creator: @Xion Xion
item.description:
@Xion wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:98, topic:230327”]Mopman, do you think a bunch of retards built the LHC? Or am I reading your comments wrong.

Anyways, Xion, I find it hard to believe you live right on top of a particle accelerator. You probably live on top of a subway.

Edit: Unless you live somewhere in a field where you are not allowed to go, I don’t see your house on this picture: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Fermilab.jpg[/quote]

Dumbass, look up fermilab… I live 2 minuits away nfrom their fucking headquarters. They have a damn hadron collider and they put it right underneath my fucking city.

Read it and weap bitch

The laboratory was founded in 1967 as the National Accelerator Laboratory; it was renamed in honor of Enrico Fermi in 1974. The lab's first director was Robert Rathbun Wilson. Many of the unique sculptures on the site are of his creation. He is attributed as being responsible for it being finished ahead of time and under budget. The high rise laboratory building located on the site, the unique shape of which has become the symbol for Fermilab, is named in his honor, and is the center of activity on the campus.

After Dr. Wilson stepped down in 1978 to protest the lack of funding for the lab, Dr. Leon M. Lederman took on the job. It was under his guidance that the original accelerator was replaced with the Tevatron accelerator, an accelerator capable of colliding a proton and an antiproton at a combined energy of 2 TeV. Dr. Lederman stepped down in 1988 and remains Director Emeritus. The on-site science education center was named in his honor.

From 1988 to 1998, the lab was run by Dr. John Peoples. From that time until June 30, 2005, the lab was run by Michael S. Witherell. On November 19, 2004 Piermaria Oddone, formerly of the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California, was announced as Fermilab’s newest Director. Oddone began his term as director July 1, 2005.

Fermilab is one of the potential sites for the proposed International Linear Collider, though the 2008 omnibus budget bill that has passed Congress makes it unlikely that the facility will be located at Fermilab.

Is that enough evidence for you??

I live in Batavia btw, incase you cant read.

Read full topic

item.title: Large Hadron Collider
item.dc:creator: @Xion Xion
item.description:
@Xion wrote:

I have one right underneath my city… Nothing has happened… No black holes, or even evidence that it caused a “big bang”. I live in batavia IL. Check it out for yourselves. There is one right underneat where I sleep, and I have lived ehre for 9 years and nothing has happened. You think these scientists would have realised by now that nothing has happened and it doesnt do anything… If it did cause a “big bag” it would have created a huge explosion… And they have not said anything about a big bang taking place with the atom smasher.

Bythe way, it has been smashing atoms for many years now…

Read full topic
